segments.text: Now, did you have any black troops assigned when you were in Germany or when you were in France?
No.
Did you have any contact at all with any of them?
Not directly.

Some of them were artillery, all right, and I'd say that in general they didn't have a very good reputation at the time, but most of them were quartermasters, support troops, not very many in the front line combat troops.
Why didn't they have a good reputation?
What was their reputation?
Well, I think that in general they were considered to be less intelligent, less qualified, and of course the intelligence matter is
is an uncertain thing at all, but certainly their background, their culture and all, they just were not up to the standard of the usual United States White troops.
They hadn't had the same background, and they didn't have quite the same motivation.
They didn't have quite the same level of skills.
They had not participated fully in our schooling and that sort of thing in those days.
but I certainly owe it to the United States Army for changing my attitude by the blacks.
Where I was reared, my family and everything certainly had discriminated against them, considered them to be inferior.
They were servants or whatever.
Of course that was my attitude along when I grew up.
And did you have servants in your household when you grew up?
on a regular basis, but black women came to do our washing and to help out at times.
Of course, even as poor as we were, you know, we could afford to have that kind of, yeah.
How about in the field on your small farm?
No, no, we didn't have any outside labor at all.
We did all the work ourselves and their family.
I did that.
Now in my father's business, he did have some blacks who worked for him.
Of course, they were always at the lower position.
They were highly segregated, of course, in all aspects.
So I was reared under a culture of sharp discrimination.
I went to the army after they integrated, after I became acquainted with some fine black people and military schools and other ways for getting over my discrimination against blacks.
Okay, now Truman desegregated the Armed Forces and started in 1947-48 and that was carried through into the early 1950s and the war in Korea.
Did your reserve units then start accepting blacks?
Sure did.
I've had some fine black officers.
The Army Reserves did that before the National Guard did too.
We had some black soldiers in my reserve artillery units around.
Many of them, on average, they were as good soldiers as I had in the white soldiers at that time.
So there again, that helped me get over my discrimination.
Was there much resistance in the reserves when Truman desegregated?
Generally, no.
In certain areas, yes.
Like my organization in Arkansas seemed to have more difficulty in accepting them than the ones in Texas.
Really?
Why do you think that would be?

Well, I think that Arkansas was still a little more rural oriented and that the blacks had a minor role in the rural areas of Arkansas still to a greater extent than they had in metropolitan areas in Texas where many of our troops were.
Louisiana
had more trouble, I had some organizations there, had more trouble integrating the blacks into the units.
I think that's because they were a higher percentage and because in general the blacks on the average in Louisiana were not as well educated as the ones in Texas.
So it wasn't without difficulty, but I wouldn't say it was a major handicap.
Now let's get back to your post-war career.
Why'd you decide to come back to Texas?
You've been a man of the world now.
I was on leave from Texas A&M and never had any other intention to come back to Texas A&M.
You never had any other desire, now that you've seen a lot of the country.
In fact, I was stimulated by my experience with the dining hall of the Department of Texas A&M, fully intended to come right back and make a career in food services.
I had done well in the dining hall, and Cliff Hotard had told me that
that if he decided to leave, he was going to recommend me to replace him.
Of course, I was very young at that time.
We were naive about it.
Sure enough, during the time I was gone, Cliff Hotar did leave and went to Dallas.
So I wrote back to President Bolton and said that I was going to leave and that I'd like to be considered for
job to replace Cliff Oktard.
I was that cocky.
I got a nice letter back from President Bolton saying of course that that wasn't possible at the time.
Old Jay Penniston, Cliff Oktard's brother-in-law replaced him.
I did come back and go to work for Jay Penniston.
In the same capacity?

capacity exactly, but I got into academics sort of accidentally at that time, because several of the professors in the Animal Science Department were, had gone, were in the military services for instance.
D.W. Williams head of department was in the Army, and F.I.
Dahlberg, who was acting head, his enrollment increased a little bit at that time,

I was off in the afternoon from one to five, so he came over and propositioned me to help him out with their freshman animal science laboratories, which I started doing because I still loved the animal science field too.
And after I did that successfully for a little while, the animal science department started paying half my salary.
And so I got into the instructor business in animal science, got interested again, enrolled and resumed my graduate work.
I was wondering why you went back to graduate school.
Well that's why.
I got involved with the animal science department again just kind of accidentally because they needed help.
I just volunteered to give them some.
Connected again with Roy Snyder, who was running the Meats Laboratory.
Got interested again in the Meats aspects.
So I resumed my graduate work for the master's degree.
Obviously, I didn't have to do anything about that.
I had to get graduate work.
So I say resumed.
What I did is to enroll and take the second half of organic chemistry, eight years after I'd taken the first half.
I was encouraged by some people, like one of the major influences my whole life was Professor C.B.
Gottlieb, who was head of the genetics department.
And I'd say of all the people that I was associated with during my entire academic career, he was the most admired man.
Why was that?
What qualities did he have?
Because he was so brilliant.
But yet, and such an outstanding teacher, but still took such an avid interest in all of his students.
Just such an outstanding man.
And I'd say that he keeps a carrot in front of me.
Stimulates you, complimenting you along the way, sign you,
Keep stretching your capability, leading you forward.
I know now that he duped me about one thing, one of the statistics, theoretical statistician, a man named Fisher.
Professor Godfrey always gave us a basis for any statistical operation we're doing.
We had to derive equations and all.
He told me he'd never been able to figure out how Fisher derived a certain equation.
Would I go to the library and study Fisher's book and explain it?
Which I did, and I'm mighty proud of myself that I could explain that.
I know now that that's just a trick.
Gotta be about to know that backwards and forwards.
So yeah.
He just wanted you to learn that.
Yeah, I got into it.
We had a small class.
The first semester of statistics, we must have had maybe 10 in the class, and the second semester of statistics, there weren't but three of us in that class at the time.
One of them was an Indian student, from India, and also a guy named Morris Garber, who was a Jewish fellow, and me.
When Godfrey would send us to the board to work out equations or something, I'd always been good at math.
I was terribly embarrassed that by the time I finished, both of them were already through.
I found out later that this Indian fellow had a master's degree in mathematics from Harvard.
And Morris Garber was just one of the real brilliant guys.
Made a career in teaching statistics first year and then at the University of California.
So I was overmatched in that class.
Then you decided to go on and get a PhD, and this was at Michigan State.
Why did you choose Michigan State?
Why didn't you stay here?
Well, in the first place, I was still under financial stress, young family.
But we got an opportunity to apply for what was called General Education Board
fellowships of the Rockefeller Foundation.
Now that was a the general education board was an operation of Rockefeller where he was hoping to increase the training of professional people in the colleges of the south.
So I was awarded one of those fellowships so that I could go anywhere I chose and I
By that time I was active in national meats societies, the reciprocal meat conference specifically, and I learned to respect a man named L.J.
Bratzler at Michigan State University because he had the best blend of the theoretical and practical knowledge of meats of anybody in the country, in my opinion.
So I went to Michigan State University to work with him.
That's why I chose Michigan State actually.
This must have been a great cultural shock for you to go and become a Yankee for a couple of years.
Well it was.
To see snow.
It was.
I remember we left College Station in September.
It was 105 degrees and we got to East Lansing, Michigan.
It was 60 or something like that.
My young family and I immediately had respiratory problems.
And we were not looking forward to spending winters in the frozen north.
Remember, my wife and I spent our first winter together at Onalaska, Wisconsin, and so we were not unfamiliar with the north.
But I just came.
appreciate enough and praise enough the people in the Animal Science Department, the Animal Husbandry Department of Michigan State University, how they embraced us, took us in, made us feel welcome.
Did you get the same quality student-teacher relationship at Michigan State, do you feel, that you had here?
Yes, I did.
Outstanding.
I got into biochemistry up there.
Was one of the pioneers in the animal husbandry department to work in food science and really take up the background of chemistry required for that.
But the statistics professor, a man named Beaton, was a Texan.
He graduated from Baylor University, where he got his Ph.D.
But anyway, that was taught in the math department up there.
Brasler lived up fully to my expectation.
He was a really fine man with an unusual mastery of theoretical and practical aspects of meats.
So I'm certain that
I had some divine guidance or something there.
It was a very, very fine experience.
This must have really broadened you because you had all your undergraduate and master's degree here at Texas A&M.
This must have been a good experience for you.
Well it was, but still the coursework I've taken here was up to the standard of Michigan State.
The chemistry courses I had here were very, very rigorous.
That gave me excellent training background for the biochemistry work.
The statistics I had with God be here, excellent.
So while I worked hard at Michigan State,
It wasn't beyond the capability at all, based upon very good background in Texas A&M.
Okay, and then when you graduated with your PhD, did you have the job waiting for you here?
Yes, I was on leave from a position in the Animal Science Department all the time I was at Michigan State.
It was an obligation on the part of Animal Science that I wouldn't
I did not have any subsidy of any kind from Texas A&M, so I could have taken an employment elsewhere.
My wife- Did you consider that?
Yes, we were offered a job in Chicago.
Okay.
Had almost twice the salary that I could make at Texas A&M.
Really?
My wife- Where?
Where in Chicago?
Well, at the American Meat Institute Foundation, a research organization funded by the Packers.
at the University of Chicago.
My wife and I seriously considered that.
We also could have stayed at Michigan State University.
Really?
They would have given you an assistant professorship?
Well, no, I don't know what the rank was, but I think yes, probably assistant professor.
There was an extension position in Meach that they were starting that they talked to me about.
Never made a firm offer.
My wife and I considered everything, and we decided life was too short to live in Chicago, and we came right back to Texas A&M.
Had the same salary I left for, $5,700 a year.
So that, again, must have been divine guidance, because within two years after we had decided that, well, three years later,
the whole American Meat Institute Foundation thing was zeroed out by the packing industry.
So we would not have had a very long career with them.
By that time I was department head of the Animal Science Department.
Why did you decide not to accept that position up at Michigan State?
Sounds like a good starting point.
Oh, we were just two provincial Texans.
You just wanted to come back to Texas?
Just wanted to come back to Texas.
That's where we had our roots.
We just liked Texas, and just like Texas A&M.
Liked what I was doing with the meat section, the animal science people here.
Jack Miller, who lives right here right now, was department head.
We were very fond of him.
So we decided that the financial difference wasn't worth it.
In June of 1950, the North Koreans invaded the South Koreans, and yet you were in the reserves at this time, and you were not called into active duty.
Why was that?
Well, our reserve outfit wasn't called.
We surely were vulnerable to a call.
Even though you were in the artillery?
You weren't called?
I mean- Well, because we were in a military organization, that is the C and
By that time, I believe, I'm not sure exactly whether we were in the 90s.
You were in the Armored Field Artillery.
You were the commander of the 352nd Armored Field Battalion.
Okay, that's 22nd Armored Division or something like that, so you see that no major units were called at all.
Individual reservists were called, but not any.
reserves that were functioning in larger military, no large military organization was called at all.
So of course- So you relied on individuals that they needed and- That's right, that's right.
And of course recruiting for the reserves was mighty easy along the time because that was one way of carrying out a person's military responsibility.
Well what's the effect of that war on the reserves?
Increasing
desire to volunteer?
We had fantastic capability.
We had a lot of ROTC cadets in our military outfit for instance.
It wasn't unusual to have enlisted men with master's degrees.
We had fantastic capability during the draft period in the reserves.
We'd have a waiting list
There was no recruiting problem, whatever.
Would you think of people who would rather be in the reserves than volunteer for active duty?
Do you have any feelings on that?
Certainly not.
As my sons do that, that was one alternative.
It was a good alternative where they would have been able to make a contribution in case of general war or whatever.
So I thought that it was an intelligent decision.
Did you volunteer for duty, active duty in Korea?
No.
What did you think about the war itself?
Oh, I had mixed emotions about it.
I felt like I really didn't have enough knowledge to have a firm opinion or attitude about it.
I deplored the no-win tactics that we used there and used later in Vietnam.
Because any experience I had is you exercised every superiority you could.
Of course by that time we had nuclear capability, extremely dominant forces in the world.
Of course I thought we should have tried to win the war, just like MacArthur apparently thought so.

Were you in favor of using, I know that you weren't in a position of military power, but did you go along with MacArthur or were you in favor of airstrikes north of the Yellow River and using the nuclear capability?
All of my training had been to try to
to engineer superiority and use it to the maximum.
That's the way you win battles and save lives.
So you bet, I sure was for exercising our superior strength and advantage in any way we could.
Still am.
Unfortunately, we've lost a lot of that edge along
I'm going to deplore that.
I'm sorry, babe.
Let's talk for a minute about the effects of McCarthyism and really rampant anti-communism in the 1950s throughout this country.
What effect did it have on the reserves?
Any?
Boy, I don't know.
know of any.
I'd say that in general the thinking people, well-educated people, did not favor McCarthy tactics and really thought that the threat was being exaggerated.
Though
nobody really was interested in having any organized resistance.
There weren't as, there just wasn't as likely, people were not as likely to take up a cause and take up the other side among people that I associated with.
Here at Texas A&M?
Yeah, right.
And then the reserves and wherever they
were inclined to try to further their own careers.
They were generally Anglo-Saxon, Protestant, conservative people.
Okay, and at this time, in the 1950s, you were in the Army Reserve with a con group.
What's the con group?
Let's see what this is.
That is the, let's see, during that time, you see, I was at Michigan State University, so really that was non-assigned personnel, and these were people that were
authorized to retain their commissions.
They were not paid for any drills.
So you were sort of inactive reserve.
That's right.
You see, during the period I was in 51 to 53 at Michigan State University, I didn't have time for any reserve activities, and I didn't participate in any reserve activities at all.
So they pretty much gave you time off.
Control group is what that is.
The abbreviation for that is control group.
Okay, and then you returned to Research and Development Unit.
That's right.
What types of functions did you have there?
The Research and Development Unit was composed of faculty members at Texas A&M University.
They met for points only, and this was composed of Navy, Air Force, Army people.
Fred Benson, for instance, was in it from the Navy side.
Again, we were not paid for drills.
We met on campus in one of the lecture rooms somewhere.
We would go for two weeks of active duty somewhere in the summer.
Actually, I wasn't with it long enough ever to go into that.
It was a pool of people that had good technical training based upon their professional qualifications.
Were there certain things that you would take out in the field in research and development?
Were there any new developments that you had to experiment with?
No.
It was a seminar type group.
And they were, as far as I know, was assigned in your mission.
It was just kind of a holding group for technically qualified people.
And we were exposed to advances and developments of weaponry, tactics, or whatever, but not called- So it was more educational then?
Yes, it was.
Maintained skills and developed skills further.
Okay, and then in 1955 to 1959 you became the CO of a battalion.
Yeah, I resumed that.
I was commander of a battalion before I went to Michigan and really assumed command again of the same battalion.
The battalion had been re-designated, but it was the same outfit as headquarters right here.
I see, but you were never, did you ever have a command of a company?
Well, I had the command of a battery in World War II.
So that would put you in line and give you the experience for the command of a battalion.
Sure.
As you say, I came out of World War II a major.
That's beyond the company level kind of grade.
I was field grade officer.
What was your rank then?
became the company commander of the 343rd Fuel Artillery.
I was a major.
You were still a major at that time.
Matter of fact, early on I was a major and I was pretty resentful of the fact that I commanded a battalion for
three or four years and never got promoted to lieutenant colonel because at that time I was considered to be too young to lieutenant colonel.
So that proved to be lucky later.
What did you do in the battalion, the field artillery battalion, basically training?
Oh yes, yes we trained and
my battalions we would sometimes go for weekend training Fort Hood for firing exercises.
We did just like we did in training in the active army.
Okay and how many men did you have under your command?
Well a battalion we were authorized at that time I believe 80 percent of full strength
So by that time I think the battalion was about 400 men, officers and men.
How many staff officers did you have working under you?
About a dozen, something like that.
What was the quality of the reserve?
Was it still high?
The quality of reserves around Bryan, Texas has always been outstanding because there's so many
graduates of Texas A&M and they chose to stay active.
